review_title: Management has a plan, but execution is poor
pros:
Clear goals on where the bank is going
Flexible employees' benefits scheme
cons:
Poor and not well-defined corporate governance standards and policies
Fractured roles and responsibilities within the Group - no clear ownership of roles
IT is not in control of technology governance standards; there is a tendency to bypass it altogether by critical divisions such as Treasury.
Technological risks largely present but yet to be uncovered - eg network security outside of the data centre is questionable
Large number of systems that cannot be linked to each other, outdated technology infrastructure
Inflexible systems have resulted in the need for manual processes to the point of performing the same data entry in different systems for a single transaction
Disparate systems have resulted in the inability to present a single view of a customer's bank relationship to the front-line 
Not big on CRM initiatives - still at Siebel v7 
Still struggling process-wise, only beginning to implement activity-based costing. Processes are lengthy and unmeaningful, ageing operations workforce
HR: Inability to retain young talent in the backroom which could lead to potential leadership renewal issues
Has just started looking at data as a tool in decision making

pros:
The GTP / MA programme at OCBC Bank has been a fruitful and fulfilling one. As a graduate talent of Group Operations & Technology division, the structured rotational programmes allowed me to have a meaningful stint in several technology roles, with exposure to risk and prevention efforts within the division.

Besides the technical aspects of work, the HR talent management has engaged us regularly to attend useful trainings to enhance our soft skills in areas of personal effectiveness, personal leadership and how to better manage our career growth in years to come.

There are also many opportunities to interact with and hear different perspectives from various OCBC's key leadership appointment holders at the annual graduate talent regional week, and meet our batch mates from overseas offices such as OCBC Malaysia and OCBC NISP. 

These are the many benefits that graduate talents could receive, as compared to normal direct hires into the various business units.
They provide free breakfast and lunch
cons: There is no 13th month pay and there is no declaration of bonus for this year at all because their revenue drops by 20%. Even when their previous years profit are good they also gave only 1.2 months bonus without 13th month pay. And their 1.2 months bonus are divided by six months instalment!

review_title: Transformation is mostly all-talk and execution is weak
pros: Good, stable place, and good benefits where relationship is valued more than the role/position. Work culture depends on the team/dept. but generally fine except in O&T where leadership is authoritarian/top-down know-it-all culture - there are certain bullying and abusive senior characters to watch out
cons:
- Marketing has been over the top with less real action on the ground - be it investment, FinTech or Digital transformation - more reactive after other banks have started and there was market pressure to show something (Bank does not want to spend and cut costs all the time)
- Many competing parties to get limelight vs. what is good for shareholders/company (FinTech, GO&T, Data fight is the most recent fight around this)

review_title: Enterprise Banking (Lending) - a toxic working environment
pros:
- Good induction training programme for new hires
- Transparent initial career advancement roadmap
- Decent compensation package across industry
cons:
Middle-level management treats employees with no respect, and as if they are school children. Lots of time wasted in the mornings on department-wide naggings, about the importance of showing up for work by 9am, being productive by not buying coffee during working hours, and on getting lost and leaving if one is unhappy with the department. Rampant fraud and rule-breaking tolerated, all to drive case counts and sales numbers committed to senior management. No wonder yearly staff turnover is around 60% or more.

Employee Engagement Survey responses by staff are also artificially influenced by the management. Team leaders are asked to watch over their employees during the survey, and to prevent them from putting anything less than 100%, so as to "obtain the best funding and resources from the CEO's office". Some team leaders even force their staff to hand over their mouse for them to check through their survey responses before submitting!!!

pros: good pay, good colleagues who are mainly Singaporeans. zero politics
cons:
long working hours, you are not paid for overtime but expected to work overtime if you cannot complete your work within working hours. very fast paced cal center. the systems used is very backdated resulting in longer after call work. 
constant negative changes by the bank resulting in alot more unhappy customers and more call in and complains to handle
high call volume and on average a customer waits on the line for about 30 mins before being served, can you imagine the customers mood and intonation when the line gets finally picked up ?

review_title: Pros and Cons of working at OCBC Bank
pros: Family orientated culture and tightly knitted bunch of colleagues, perfect workplace for expectant mothers and people who want a stable job and fixed income. Most people are overall very friendly and appreciate internal cross department partnerships. Special mention to the CEO as I get the general sense that he really cares for his staff and the well being of most employees.
cons: Old fashioned way of working and slow to adapt and implement new technological and industry practices. Limited budget for implementation and very bureaucratic process of identifying problems and rolling out changes or updates. There is always a continual pressure on sales staff to value add to a sometimes uncompetitive product and pricing: this in turn causes fatigue in the long run. Personally, I feel that there is a risk that the organisation might slowly lag behind its competitors and other newer forms of banking or financial services if it keeps focusing on growing it's existing businesses the same old way without attempting to try new methods or technology.

pros: Overall good experience with good exposure in the area of compliance. Freedom is given to employee (of certain role) to excel in a job (ie Drive a project or contribute knowledge to the whole bank). Steep learning curve, but if you can embrace this stress, you can benefit in this area in a long run.
cons: People that have been in the bank for too long tend to be complacent and think that they know all. Also unwilling to listen to junior staff that actually do have more knowledge than them. Afraid to take ownership and provide approval for matters. Need to build up more knowledge to ensure that they do not just benchmark themselves against the local banks but against the global banks and the industry.

review_title: Didn't know what I sign up for
pros: -- Good number of leaves, bonus.
cons:
-- Irregular working hours. Project managers and Managers consider people to be available 24*7 and never ask before calling them to the office.
-- A lot of overtime needs to be done and projects are not properly planned because the delivery timelines are very tight. Most people I have worked with suffer from stress.
-- People are not technologically advanced as recently a lot of people have left the banks because of No-work life balance
-- Only join if you are 100% dedicated to your work and dont have a life outside the job.

review_title: What I have gained while working in OCBC
job_title: Part Time Administrative Staff in Singapore
pros: The working environment in OCBC is very people-friendly, productive and conducive. The people in OCBC are generally helpful, supportive and kind which was one of plus point that helped me adapt to the working environment quickly.
cons: I feel that there should be more bonding session between departments where we will get to know each other better. Even though, we might not be working on projects together, we should still be a big family together.

pros: For fresh graduate, company offers many chance to  learn many things like banking system, operation, product knowledge, how to manage people, and what is macro management. Lastly, you will be able to improve yourself on how to endure high stress. Can train your mental.
cons: Nobody teaches juniors, juniors must stand up themselves, no work life Balance. No life is your life once you take this job. Everyday you will suffer gastric and feel nauseous. Either you lose weight or gain weight, no matter, what your health cannot be healthier than now.  No personal time. Need to work like mad dog. Very macro managed, some people scold you everyday even they though didn’t teach you at all. They point out on makeup and attires. Sometimes you will be very confused whether you are working at the bank or at Model entertainment company. Even though you are closing deal with client at your branch, they will turn off the light and shout to you. Very unreasonable company.

review_title: Relationship Manager in OCBC Singapore Premier Banking
pros: Training and development courses provided. Management used to be supportive and business oriented but has since been on downward sloping.
cons: Business process is poor and slow. Focused too much on compliance and audit, hence too many red tapes surfacing. Most managers do not know how to help employees to grow and solve problems, only wants sales numbers! Poor supporting structure if you want to grow your business. Management is weak. Does not understand grass root staffs. Placed too much unnecessary resources on arts at banking hall and occasional exhibition / online banking thumb print access etc. These may NOT be what clients need the most.

review_title: Good starting point for fresh grads
pros: High basic and alright commissions. Clear career path (Management or Sales tracks). Getting $4k-5k+ a month is achievable if you hustle hard. Good career for fresh grads who want to stay close to the money and potentially move to other roles in the front office.
cons: All banking RMs in s'pore are glorified insurance agents. There is no sense of fiduciary duty towards the client because management expects you to push the product that generates the most revenue. You are expected to brainwash clients.

review_title: Depends on luck, which dept you're in
pros: good working location. You'll be able to survive if you don't mind playing office politics.
cons: Lots of politics, dept people are not that friendly and helpful. When they need your help, they'll be nice to you. But when you need help from them, they'll tell you "all the while is like that" or act busy, not helpful at all. Long waiting time for getting access and you totally have no idea who you can contact. They'll tell you since you've fax your request over, then wait for their email.

pros:
Stability. Conservative which serve well in current uncertain economic condition. A good training ground for new starter in the banking industry.
Bank will compensate well for the right candidate to join the company. However, the pay rise thereafter is typically lower than the industry standard.
Bank provide much stablity by not retrenching its employee during the downtime.
Training is usually in-house by senior management rather than external trainers.
Due to the bank cost conscious approach, working environment might not be that pleasant. Old furniture, IT equipment, etc...
The iconic building is on the list for conservation.. thus many upgradings have to forgo.
cons: Compensation less attractive as compare to most foreign banks.

pros:
- Flexible working hours at the branch. Able to meet clients at own time.
- Basic pay is not too bad. Many incentives for higher commission.
- Good initial training and orientation programme.
cons:
- Management who only look at sales numbers and targets, not employee development. Seem to prefer the easier route of pressuring and terminating sales staff rather than training them or allowing them to do an internal transfer to different departments.
- Not flexible with internal job transfer process.

review_title: I used to be a manager in OCBC
pros:
Upper management seems keen on staff welfare. Time to time, staff will receive little goodies from the management, such as brownies, N95 mask. It is a good approach to know that the organisation still care about its staffs.

OCBC attempts to bring about colleagues cohesion with sport day, outings/
cons:
Commission payout is only verbal based and not written on anywhere, including the contract despite clearly being a commission incentive job. Payout will only be known months later and definitely lesser than the previous year. Staffs have no right to dispute if the payout is paid later than the verbal agreement, which is every quarterly, nor get a single cent if they choose to leave before the payout date.

Direct superior tends to micro manage and have apparent biases among subordinates. It felt like I am back in my primary school day where I are supposed to report every single movement.

Vulgarities were used on subordinates as and when the superior thinks it is necessary. Such as late reply to superior after working hours.

Double standard can be seen between top management and middle management. Subordinates like me, had to adhere to middle management (cutting corners and meeting KPIs) while lying to top management that we are adhering to theirs (delivering quality to consumers).

Feedback to the top management is equally controlled. Subordinates have to go through with their direct superiors what they are going to say and what is allowed. 

Internal transfer is only after 1.5 year - 2 years based on management approval hence only option for one to move out of the department is to wait and hope that OCBC approves your transfer or quit.

pros: Good environment, friendly people who are generally smart and have eclectic backgrounds. You get a lot of freedom to resolve issues. Benefits are decent, and you are working someplace people respect.
cons: Lower salaries than other companies, so there is more churn than ideal. Getting time off can be a real problem when you are a Senior Advisor/Tier 2 because there just aren't many hours available. Your experience depends almost entirely on how good your manager is, and there are some bad managers. The extreme secrecy about everything can be counterproductive.

review_title: Needs improvement in the area of IT development
pros:
- As a local company, fortunately it has not sold itself out to Indians completely compared to many other companies especially in the area of IT. 

- A well-managed HR team with relatively good employee benefits.
cons:
- No work-life balance, project timeline are ridiculously planned with frequent scope changes.

- Crazily tight security policies which hinders development process drastically.

- Too much reliance on vendors whom are expensive and does not necessarily deliver in quality.

pros:

- Good initiatives to encourage family-friendliness or drive sustainability.
cons:

- Visionary ideas from the top but senior managers lack direction to make it a reality
- Most senior leaders only care about pleasing the management, and will rush to do things out of fear without thinking things through.

review_title: A Great Place to Work and Growth
pros: The culture of working in OCBC Bank is fantastic. The management are really into the staff's development and progress, they provided a lot of trainings and opportunities for one to advance and learn.
cons: The culture is sometimes a cons as well. It provided a good and comfortable environment to work, so sometimes people are reluctant to climb out from their comfort zones to challenge new opportunities

With sarcastic, slave-driving People Managers, only the strong can survive.
Best to come in at AVP and progress. Those who start at the bottom usually get weeded out within 10 years

temp staff are treated as if they are invisible/kids. Came out with stupid reasons to think staff was born yesterday
terrible management
"team lead" always too busy and don't trust the hard work that employee do

short handed and no one wants to work at the dept.

pros:
OCBC Bank is a fantastic place to work, consisting of transparent leadership and an incredible company culture. Our employees truly stand behind the company mission... We help people.

Each day brings a new and exciting challenge. The senior leadership team cares for their employees, always putting us first.

The focus on work life balance is incredible. With WFH capabilities too (great in a time like this). I can't imagine myself anywhere else.
cons: The way they kept track of their metrics didn't make sense which made the job super stressful. The worst part was they knew too and really didn't care that much.

review_title: Good training but tough transition to the branch
pros:
Very comprehensive training in the OCBC campus before being posted out to the branch. 

Good base pay for a fresh graduate, about $3.3k for a degree holder and on top of that, you get commissions. 

If you're lucky, you might be posted to a branch with a very endearing branch manager.
cons:
The transition to the branch was tough, it was a steep learning curve but that's fine, as which any new environment and job. 

The line ever "every man for himself" struck hard and was very apparent. Seniors in the same role as I was were not as patient and helpful when it comes to teaching. Perhaps, the seniors saw the newer ones as a threat since it was a sales role after all. 

On top of that, the service officers whom we had to work with quite a fair bit to authorize certain transactions & AML checks and checking of paper work were 90% unpleasant. I understand it is a taxing role but it is not fair to bear the brunt whenever we require their assistance, which is a few times a day depending on the kind of transaction. 

I cannot speak for all the branches in Singapore but this is just my experience my particular branch. Work/life balance is also subjective depending on the type of branch you get posted to, whether it's Sunday banking or not. If so, the traffic is higher on weekends and most colleagues will still come back to work.

pros:
Strong believer of training and development. 

Understands the balance of work and fun.

Cares for employees welfare by having frequent catch ups with your line manager.
cons:
Should understand the job nature of each individual and managers should not be treating employees as resources. 

Managers and experienced colleagues need to understand the need of having to include new employees into the social groups.

pros:
Remuneration is fairly high considered a role without any experience needed
Colleagues are friendly and helpful
cons:
Long hours - Prepare to sell your life to the bank and be their slave as you will be working everyday even on weekends and public holidays. 
Tons of paperwork and lousy processing system - a simple case can take forever to process as there are too many middlemen involved.
Not much transferable skill sets to be learnt - ultimately it is a sales position. you are only required to sell and sell your product.

pros:
Am at the Global Treasury so the review is only for this floor. 
Very friendly environment, easy to talk to anyone even if you are relatively junior.
Lots to learn, somewhat fast pace environment but not taxing on the hours.
Family oriented, look forward to coming to work as a result.
Decent amounts of leave, good work life balance. 
Bank Stay Trues and is Simply Spot On. Practices good ethics overall.
cons: No real cons but progress would probably be faster if you join from a foreign bank.

pros: Very Friendly Work Culture. Managers are willing to groom and teach. Good place to start your career. Growing innovation culture that is not afraid to explore new ways and technology for banking.
cons: Lack of Global exposure and presence. Base pay is not as high as most International Banks. Pace of work can be slow at times with a lot of unnecessary red tapes.

review_title: Good stepping ground but bad working culture

Being HQ, less restrictions and red tapes in spear heading new ideas.
cons:

pros:

Good Training and Development program.

cons: Some managers (VP3-1) only see talkers than doers, doesn't know how to motivate and empower people, lack of vision, lack of trust. No work-life-balance for those working on the ground. review_title: family oriented bank but cut throat environment
pros: people are nice, culture is family oriented.
cons:
I was in a front office banking sales role. it's not so much the cons of the bank but the nature of the job itself, have to pressure customers to buy financual products.

also, system wasn't fair to begin with. sales people in a low traffic branch have a much harder time hitting targets. to the bank, there's no loss. this job is about survival of the fittest.

job_title: Trade Finance Officer in Tampines New Town,
pros: OCBC is known for its good staff benefits and welfare
cons: Poor culture, poor environment, lots of politics, "kampong behaviours" (gossiping/judgmental/jealousy/controlling) from the aging workers who have been stuck there for decades. Older workers are not receptive to better working methods/style/arrangements - a typical aging work environment, they are complacent with their repetitive tasks, enjoy lots of sugar-coated compliments, exercise biased decision making, throwing logic out the window and tend to suppress the younger workers. Definitely not a great environment for growth.

review_title: Terrible environment for professionals in O&T

cons: Terrible and dictatorial management and no concept of leadership - only self interest. Create situations to make departments fight with each other with no strategic or common sense thinking. Interested only in their bonuses and people transfer to business-side in droves at the earliest opportunity or leave altogether

cons: Long working hours, lack of job recognition, conservative culture, high sales target which leads to stress, constant pressure from management to sell more products, causing product-pushing to occur on the ground

pros: Family Culture, good colleagues, rewards well if you can perform well, flexibility in sales as they do not really micro manage, 24 days of leave is more than enough

review_title: Think twice before jumping into this job (PFC)
pros:
Great work environment except for BM. Dependant on where you are posted.
High basic.
cons:
Don't expect to knock off on time if you work frontline.
Long hours.
On top of servicing, have to hit sales target.
Have to pay $3000 bond if you wish to quit.
Overly rigid and compliant. 
Complicated variable comission structure.
Massive paperwork. If you are looking to earn good money, other sales job will give you better salary with less paperwork.

review_title: Toxic work environment with no vision for It growth
pros:
Good leave and medical benefits
Relaxed work hours and job safety
Variety of courses available on employee learning on sift skills improvement (subject to approval from boss)
cons:
-Though many courses are available for employee development they are more on soft skills and will not improve employees on technical skills
-No growth potential in terms of salaries, bonuses and promotion
- You will see lot of demotivated people around you
- Management not ready to spend on IT projects and have very conservative approach
- Employee satisfaction survey is manipulated and boss discourages you from giving real ratings.

review_title: A good place to start if you lack relevant banking experience
pros:
Young environment
Lots of friendly colleagues
Average Pay
Well-known for their L&D initiatives
cons:
Lack of professional development opportunities
Didn't get to enjoy courses at its L&D center due to management directive that sales are supposed to run sales and that these courses are not useful in churning out numbers

review_title: Wont care much for staff, just want to keep operations going.
pros: Good pay and good starting ground for fresh grad before moving to next company
cons: Working long hours and not appreciated. Does not care about staff welfare, only looking at results and figures. Not much help, pretty much left to learn and fend for yourself. training and teaching are just system to follow through, no human touch.

review_title: Run as a traditional bank in Technology & Operations department
pros: Opportunities are given to those who are committed, working hard for the department. The bank is transformation into a digital bank.
cons: Hierarchical structure, with limited opportunity for advancement. Work exceptional hard to get an average bonus of 3 months.

review_title: Slow pace wins the race (suitable place for grinders, slackers, and useless people in general)
pros: not too terrible bonus, slow and relaxing pace of life, deadlines dont' appear to be deadset, job security, almost reminiscent of government job
cons: lots of useless and unproductive deadweight staff, progression appears to be based on age, seniority and hours spent in office rather than productivity and results

pros: Great salary, benefits and leave. Good working environment, nice collegues and boss.
cons: Sales role, practical, do not hit target, pay bond of $3000 and shoo. Cluster Manager will squeeze you dry. Do not offer internal job transfer unless you have served 1.5yrs. Even so, very hard to transfer.

pros: Love the family oriented culture. Bank is willing to train and develop its staff. Good work life balance too. Stable working environment as well.
cons: Can be a little hierarchical due to the many rank structure. Though it is pretty structured for career development, it can be a little bureaucratic at times.

pros:
Challenging, fast-pace, and procedures orientated. 
Projects that really impact the society and life.
cons: Cultures and direction is contradicting. High up said must up skill and innovate, but the actual rewards to management team is cost saving.

review_title: Good or bad really depends on role
pros:
Challenging tasks, responsibilities are issued quickly at work. 
Helpful and approachable colleagues who are willing to teach and guide juniors.
cons:
Low starting base compared to peers, progression is slow and rigid, lack of transparency on career progression. 
Long hours (but really depends on role/function). 
A lot of inflexibility and rigidity on the corporate front that hinders business opportunities.

pros: Good exposure to the local banking scene. Lots of stuff to pick up. Excellent compensation and benefits for the organization as a whole.
cons: Steep learning curve as there are endless things to learn on products and systems. Can be extremely stressful. Mundane.

pros: Good Starting Pay for Fresh Graduates. Good Benefits. Sales role enable one to have a good exposure to people from all sorts of life.
cons: Long working hours. High pressure to perform so as to meet sales target on a monthly basis. Managers can be pressurizing and very micro about daily activities. Integrity Dilemma while trying to sell the proper financial product and trying to hit your sales target.

pros: The work culture is good, colleagues are friendly and helpful. Bosses are knowledgable and helpful. Work benefits are good as well.
cons: Too much paper work. Process wise, there are certain things that cannot be controlled, leading to slower turnaround time. Working hours are long as it is a sales job

pros: Great pay to do next-to-nothing. A great amount of life, in the work-life balance equation. Too big to fail.
cons:
People take 2-3 hour lunches, are constantly late for meetings, or plain just forget to show up and that's just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to symptoms of people doing the bare minimum to get by and still get their fat pay cheques and ridiculous amount of leave. 

Once you work at OCBC, you can forget about building a career. In fact, my skills-bank definitely took a hit by working there. And the funny thing is that they keep thinking that they're at the fore-front and thought-leaders in banking. What a joke. I would say that the work-skills used is actually at least a decade behind others. No learning possible here.

pros: Decent work life balance. Opportunities to learn through additional projects, on top of BAU. Easy to reach out to other departments. Some nice and helpful staffs.
cons: Incompetent boss who is desperately holding on to power, mostly through the use of politics. Places her/his trust mostly in incompetent people who "sworn allegiance" to her/ him. Making progression rather difficult.

pros:
- Colleagues are generally warm and friendly.
- Pay and benefits are competitive compared to other foreign banks.
- The CEO genuinely cares for employees
- Working hours can be pretty long but are sustainable
cons:
- Too many long-serving employees who are not keeping up with the pace of change; hinder the progression of the bank to be a forward-looking company
- Need to beef up IT infrastructure

pros: Training settings and trainer are experienced
cons:
Training has take too long. 
It's bureaucratic
Very conservative 
Colleagues are too busy to assist newbie

review_title: Little investment on training and development but good pay.
pros: High availability of walk-in clients because neighbourhood branches are very crowded. This translates to higher sales if you know how to close on them.
cons: Lack of training. Short-term orientation as all focus is only on short-term revenues. Lack of communication on the vision, if any, for the next 5 to 10 years.

pros: Family bank, everyone is nice. The team that I work in is exceptionally nice and are very willing to share and guide freshies.
cons: The pay is not as competitive as what foreign banks are offering. In addition, the exposure given is not as wide.

pros: Good opportunity to learn and  grow for part time undergraduate students and also have a lot of opportunity to interact with the staffs in OCBC bank such as personal financial consultant and bank tellers
cons: Have to work on weekends and there is no flexible time slots. Room for improvements for the welfare benefits and the salary. In addition, there also must have more training provided

pros: Family Culture, Open. Well-balanced lifestyle is possible and manageable Provides guidance and grooming in your career.
cons: Some processes might get slightly sluggish, not for the overzealous and competitive people. Team focused and individualistic people would stand to lose

review_title: So-so medical benefit but corp pass has good selections
pros: Subsidised in-house childcare available. Ideal for parents. Convenient to pick up and drop off kids to school. Corp pass selections is good
cons: Work can be quite hectic. Bank has more younger generation woking compared to other locals banks. New way of doing things

review_title: Steep learning curve with lots of opportunity
pros: Their benefits and incentives are good. The bank provided very good training and ensure all staff have the knowlegde and uphold the values of the bank. Corporate culture is very strong. People are nice to work with.
cons: There is a lot of responsibility and autonomy. Excellence and performance is expected of employees.

review_title: Tough job, but if you survive it's pretty good
pros: Good company benefits, friendly colleagues and clan culture. Bosses are supportive and talent development department is well established. Products are pretty attractive to customers
cons: All about targets and customers can call you anytime. Banca is the core so you really have to be able to sell insurance even if you don't want to.

pros: company is stable. The work environment is generally good with minimum politics. Since teams are lean there is more opportunity to learn and get cross trained.
cons: Growth in responsibilities and pay is slower than foreign banks. Decision making is very centralized and too heavy. Since teams are lean and budgets tight of late, spikes in workload can impact work life balance

review_title: Good starting learning experience for fresh grads and a relatively okay place if you're chasing $.
pros: Commissions are not bad for their Bancassurance products. Strong focus on OAP products. Bank staff are friendly, flex benefits on the average side
cons: Hours are long when it comes to sales positions, expect to be working on weekends at roadshows as well if youre posted to a branch that does not open on weekends.

pros:
Friendly colleagues who are very willing to teach you
They take a lot of interns (a lot of opportunities)
People seem to stay in the company for a significant amount of years
cons:
Pace of life is slow
Not sure what the progression is like
The department that I was in was not very bonded (people usually went for lunch by themselves or ate in the office)

pros: Good working environment and culture, good teammates
cons:
No work life balance, banc focus,product push
Always indirectly forcing staff to participate in their fundraising campaign as the management will keep blasting who leading the board or allocating coupon booklet to each department for selling to others/buy it yourself instead of leaving the option to staff

pros: great environment with friendly people around in the offices.
cons: The bonus is usually a fix pie and you have to fight against your colleague to get a cut of the pie. The pie is pretty small and rarely increases by a big amount.

review_title: A great start but falters at progression
pros:
Generous in days of leave
Good Work culture and friendly colleagues
Efforts seen in attempting to improve workplace
cons:
Few career development and planning
Most of job openings are filled by external parties rather than internal staff
Felt  left out when the dept is not a profit center

pros: Few... Downtown near Raffles with a plethora of food options and commuting options.
cons: Most people have no interest in learning or understanding why they are performing the task, their only desire is to push the bottons/complete tasks and make money. People who do nothing stay here easily as they have high tolerance for incompetence.

review_title: A slow pace culture best for retirees
pros: Slow pace. Good place for retirement. Suitable for early career employees who are looking for a cosy and undemanding workplace.
cons: Technology is backward and affects productivity. HR is not aware of sentiments on the ground and is not focused on employee development. Most employees have been here for a long time and lack international views.

pros:
Friendly colleagues
Not calculative about lunch hour so you are not restricted to only an hour
Nothing else i can think of
cons:
Long working hours. Expect to stay till 8-9pm.
Expect to do bau and projects concurrently. 
Salary not great. Does not justify the amount of effort you need to put in

pros: Nil. None that I can think of. There were some when I first joined, but they have become standard in the industry.
cons: Too much work, not enough staff. High turnover of new joiners. Abrasive corporate culture. Departments work in silos.

pros:
Takes pride in integrity, stable and steady local bank. Focus on good customer experiences. 
Long serving Senior management.
cons: Too Long serving senior management which may caused slow reactions to fast growing external factors .  Over  conservative which may impede new opportunities

pros: Good chinese bank. Values strong team work. Had alot of fun while working there and one big happy family. Can see that they spent a lot of money on marketing and re-branding.
cons:
Sometimes its good to be more innovative in certain operations of the business.
Lack of opportunity for internal transfer. May lose good people in the process.

review_title: A Familial workplace.. Nicest people to work with
pros: Always willing to provide exposure to younger staff. Equal opportunity for newcomers as well. The company recognizes people who do well, but the compensation may not be as high as in other foreign banks
cons: Compensation is not as high as what you would expect for some of the responsibilities that are placed under you care.

pros: - High pay of more than $10k if you can bring in good sales (only a few can reach this number)
cons:
- If you are not assigned to a high walk-in branch, you have to really good at cold-calling.
- You must have a passion for chasing sales.

pros: The pay is alright and better than other banks and the commission scheme is better than other places. So overall is great.
cons: Better pay means more workload, you are to learn more as a financial planner in OCBC. Sometimes to help a customer and not getting any sales is normal but you will get into trouble for not performing

review_title: Better staff benefits than other local banks
pros:
* Good FLEX scheme to pay for health, insurance and other expenses
* Staff reimbursements are relatively fast
* HR policies and benefits are often refreshed and enhanced
* Well-stocked pantry
cons:
* Some departments suffering from worsening work-life balance
* Management losing track of ground challenges

pros: Stability, very people centered and they are genuinely helpful
cons: Slow to change, and can be political. Silos do occur given legacies

review_title: Unable to retain talent, leaving the pioneers to run the show
pros: Very positive and friendly CEO, benefits adequate
cons: Unable to gain the deserved recognition, promotion based on the number of years spent and not based on merit

review_title: Good company to start your banking career
pros: Nurturing supervisors who are willing to impart their experiences so we have the opportunities to obtain different types of skillsets along the way. Employee Benefits is okay. Internal career switching/upgrading is also encouraged (depending on job functions & departments).
cons: Talent recognition depends on many factors; who you worked with and what are your networking skills.

pros: Being able to work in the front office was really an eye opener. Besides being exposed to the entire process of financial trading, it was a great opportunity to develop both hard and soft skills.
cons: The work involved a great deal of administrative matters, which could become mundane very quickly. Take the initiative to engaged senior colleagues to network and learn.

pros:
- Autonomy
- Friendly work environment
- Decent benefits
cons:
- Very heavy workload, usually end-to-end process management and execution down to detail is expected. 
- Hierarchy and power play still exist
- Lack of diversity and culture is still rather conservative

review_title: Personal Financial Consultant based in a branch
pros: Well-established organisation in Singapore with grassroots banking experiences with all valuable customers.
cons: The upper management is critically and micro managing all the sales staff, extreme stress loaded.

pros: Lots of events/ workshops/ training to keep staff updated and motivated. Manager will always try to motivate you to do the best you can. Company also puts in place proper benefits and incentives to ensure staff is adequately taken care of and driven.
cons: Working almost every single day

pros: Family-oriented, good work-life balance depending on which department you work for, doesn't 'hire and fire'.
cons: Slow paced, process heavy, lack of empowerment, wants to be innovative but there are too many legacy systems, issues and people.

review_title: Good benefits. Poor technology architecture and decision making
pros: Good benefits. Iconic institution of Singapore. Management realises that its been pretty late to respond to Digital disruption and trying to do more
cons: The technical architecture in corporate banking is of stone age. More than the ideas, title of the person makes more impact. Do not have a focussed strategy.

pros: Lots of exposure with regards to working with top management. Lots of growth potential beyond the bounds of Singapore. The bank gives important projects to young staff to inject some new life into the bank.
cons: Rigid. Too many old guards impeding younger generation to promote within the organization. Pay is relatively lower than its foreign counterparts

pros:
(1) willing to bring in someone from outside banking industry and train him/her. Has the patience
(2) Life / work balance although depending on roles. One hour off every friday is fantastic
(3) Although compensation not the best, but it does take care of employees during difficult time
cons: too risk averse in some areas

pros: Local bank with Local culture. Bosses are more Forgiving. Strong base of its customer. Balance sheet is strong given that it is a local bank and therefore makes lending rates competitive.
cons: Less competitive package for the employees especially if this is your first job. Management is rather Conservative for corporate banking.

pros:
Plenty of events for socialising. 
Flexible work timing.
cons:
Company and manager still retain staff who is incapable and not doing their work which is affecting other colleague as their workload is piling.
Manager sleeping in office not doing work.
Manager does not even try to unite the team.
Staff feedbacks were not taken in by management.

review_title: Pays Well, that's why we stay
pros: Generally good remuneration and benefits, and people do seem professional and helpful
cons:
Working culture is somewhat abrasive, and there's a lot of internal competition.
Unhealthy working style for raising good work standards (too much emphasis on the wrong things)

pros: Good annual leave. Marriage leave can go up to 14 days. General welfare depends a lot on department and direct supervisors. Will be a good place to learn at entry level and probably to retire too
cons: Promotion is relatively slow and salary often below market. May need to have other objectives if to stay on

pros: Good training for fresh grads. Wealth management provides plenty of support for sales folks. Friendly culture.
cons: Limited products to sell for sales staff, too focus on Bancassurance. high staff turn over. Bank not good in managing morale of sales folks, got this feeling that they would rather replace you with someone fresh, than help you regain momentum.

pros: There is commission  career progression is good if you are able to perform well. Freedom in terms of how you handle your time.
cons: Long working hours. Need to be very hardworking and effort may not be recognized. A lot of changes along the way.

review_title: Doesn't seem to be doing well
pros: The culture is quite friendly and some staff are willing to teach. Work-life balance is good.
cons: Slow-paced. Working environment is not vibrant since the average age-group is on the older end. Office hierarchy is evident and things are not efficient enough.

pros: Empowerment to employees and cooperative culture. Opportunities to move around business units for growth and the leaders led by examples
cons: Long hours and can be stressful with widen job scope. The systems have to be improved as we move to digital age

pros: Easier to get business as the bank is still expanding in their wealth sales team. Lesser competition than other local banks. Achievable targets.
cons: The amount of paper work that has to be done is simply too much. Sometimes we are asked to do jobs that's not in our jobscope because we are short handed.

pros: good job for entry level/ fresh grads who wants to try sales. The training is good and comprehensive. Good platform to jump start career.
cons: High turnover rate. Staff retention policy can be improved. Likes to overpack a branch with more staff to cope with increasing targets, thus lacking the opportunity to fully develop employees

pros: Will promote you if you can do lots of projects
cons: Hire high rankers but basically doing nothing. Leaving BAU to ground staff who work till 10-11pm daily. No welfare, no teamtalk.

review_title: not bad a place to stay - but depends on what you value
pros:
1. Colleagues are generally nice and willing to help
2. Relatively good pay and benefits
cons:
1. Lack of clear execution plans for employees to follow
2. Most teams seem to be working in silos
3. Everyone is super busy, and as such may not provide sufficient guidance

review_title: Good experience overall. Work hard, but not really play hard.
pros:
Stable working environment. Values team work. 
Once a typical Chinese working culture but is evolving with international stints blended. 
Good work-life balance. 
Comprehensive on-job training provided.
cons: Ranking system lack of clear distinction especially within the same title. This could potentially lead to lack of motivation.

pros: Great compensation package as compared to other local banks
cons: Depends on your job role. High turnover for pfc due to the stress of sales target and management push on certain sales numbers

review_title: I had the opportunity to work with top bankers in the industry.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Hougang New Town,
pros: To be able to start my career in the financial services industry; which will enable me to further develop my career in this area.
cons: The fast pace environment can be challenging at times. At the end, it's all about time and stress management.

pros:
Family like relationships with colleagues
Young crowd
Fresh grads every few months 
Good starting job
Decent salary, even for non local Uni grads
cons:
Can be too hierarchical at times 
Red tape can be frustrating at times
Middle management can be mediocre
Benefits so so only

pros: Family Culture, Good for Retiremen
cons: Tend to be more stingy on rewarding with salary increment, which entice talents to look out. If you are capable, you tend to be burnt out as the management will overload you "exposure", including trivial affairs such as arranging D&D.

pros: Good working environment. Everyone is like a family, supporting you and guiding with everything.
cons:
Lack of manpower, using short term tactics but not addressing the actual problem.
Long working hours, and very restrictive on the things you can can do during working hours.

pros: Good Recreation Club Benefits For Staff
cons: No empathy shown by direct supervisor when staff met with personal issues. Direct supervisor raises voice at staff in open concept office.

pros: Great health and dependent coverage. Very good for parents with young children. Safe and inclusive workplace.
cons: Shares plan is terrible. Very limited concept of flexi-hours. All senior management are extremely traditional and do not seem to care about retaining talent / employee engagement.

pros: Good working culture. Family oriented. Plenty of annual leave and medical leave. Colleagues mostly friendly but have to see luck.
cons: Heavy workload. Plenty of OT thus creating a no work life balance. Low pay and might not looking at newer certs attained during employment.

pros:
great system, good management, family oriented working environment. benefits is good. 
good stepping stone to start off banking career, overall training is good.
cons:
long working hours. either stay after banking hours to do paperworks/do callings/monthly branch meeting or cluster meeting
lots of events to attend to.

pros: If anyone looking for opportunities, they may go ahead with OCBC. Otherwise, I don't see any Pros. Sorry to say.
cons: Perm staff are very arrogant.

pros: Decent work culture and colleagues. Lessons taught during training for financial products were good and reports for market news were plenty
cons: Working hours may be irregular and long. Training may have been too theoretical.

pros: Opportunity to work on projects with different departments. Good CEO.
cons: The managers are not technologically savvy, and generally quite incompetent. Department is quite backward. Overall, not a good experience. Even experienced hirers can be made to do menial task such as data entry . The above represents my opinion.

review_title: Good working environment, focus on training
pros:
Provide guidance and training
Good management support
Friendly working environment
Good career growth and opportunities
Work life balance depending on the department
cons:
Relatively lower compensation compared to peer banks
Generally departments still work in silo
Too many old guards with stubborn mentality

pros: The working environment is cooperative and there are opportunities for personal development within. Senior management are very approachable and take it upon themselves to share the group's directions and strategies via direct interactions.
cons: Long working hours during peak seasons.

review_title: Local culture - want things cheap and good
pros: Work Life balance, ample leave benefits, good training opportunities
cons: slow in promotion opportunities especially for staff that grows with them, seems to value outside hires over long serving staff, lack of transparency in promotional opportunities, strong silo mentality and "Cover your bum" culture

pros: Good work life balance, friendly working environment and supportive bosses. A variety of lunch options nearby
cons: Location wise isnt the best as it is very far away from the city center. Travelling takes a long time

pros: Job stability, good and fun loving colleagues.
cons: Some of the cons could be due to your direct manager. Sometimes you might not even get bonuses or increment despite your hard work. So one has to hope that he or she ends up with a good manager.

pros:
Helpful colleagues
Young and vibrant environment
Work life balance
Alot of freebies and recreation events
Trainings provided to upgrade skillset
Get to be in projects to make changes
cons:
Process and structure keeps changing
Forms keeps changing
Manual work
Red tapes
Inexperienced people 
Tight turnaround time
Must be able to withstand changes all the time

pros: Family oriented culture and a lot of opportunities for young graduates with exposures. Very good pay for high rank positions therefore many foreign bankers jump to OCBC
cons: Have to work late everyday and emotes are very silo about their own tasks without the awareness of teamwork. Not enough innovative culture.

pros: Sustainable pace of work which encourages work life balance for employees. There is a family like culture which is unexpected of a bank.
cons: The life might be too slow for some people. However my views might be limited to the department which I interned, thus not reflective of the entire firm.

pros: Great family-oriented culture internally within the department, places emphasis on employee satisfaction. Recognition for projects and process improvements. Good L&D team with meaningful training programs for work-related and self-development.
cons: Certain internal applications are not well-connected or integrated for smooth processing.

review_title: Very ambitious bank that simply ignores staff welfare.
pros: You'll learn from the most elitist office 'politicians'.
cons:
Zero work life balance, you'll be judge as lazy if you leave work on time.
Frequently have your ideas/work stolen for credits, leaving you with nothing.
Managers does not encourage skill-set training, ask staffs to show the money on the table before applying for courses.
Senior management rules by fear, vulgarities has become a norm, and then it cascades downwards.

pros: Good all round benefit for employees. Lots of leave, some flex and insurance benefits and plenty of training workshops to choose from
cons: Too cautious and slow to respond to trends. Most of the time the bank will see how others respond first before making a decision

pros: Compare to other company the benefit is not so bad.
cons:
1. no work-life balance
2. security policy slow down whole development process
3. only two testing devices can be used for development
4. developer need to test reported bugs, ie: no QA in team

review_title: Great culture, but internal processes need to be updated
job_title: Manager, Business Development in Houston, TX
pros: Family oriented culture. Majority of full time teams are local Singaporeans. Great emphasis on team-bonding, good leadership in certain departments.
cons: Back end processes are very manual and new initiatives can be slow to implement

review_title: Slow to change but generally fair towards employees
job_title: Head of Human Resources Asia in Singapore
pros: Systematic approach to HR change management with good governance in place
cons: Difficult to attract best in class talent to bring about much needed process automation and improve efficiency

pros: Pro family benefits such as leave and medical benefits. Have good supportive colleagues depending on department
cons: Performance review and salary adjustments not aligned. Some senior staff are over-rated. Poor horizontal mobility in career as transfers face a number of level of scrutiny. Moving out is easier.

pros: Diverse, dynamic and there's quite a number of perks for employees.
cons: Minimal work-life balance and the socio-politics in the workplace is quite horrible. The promise of good remuneration and/or performance bonuses is entirely dependent if your immediate supervisor or team lead likes you.

pros: Excellent place to start your career, with a great learning environment if you are self motivated and willing to take on more duties. Senior management provides personal feedback and motivation.
cons: Long hours and tight timeline. Might not be able to carry out self satisfactory analysis for work done.

review_title: Good position to start off in banking.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Outram Park,
pros: Good place and culture for people who want to start in a sales position in a bank. Coms are relatively attractive.
cons: Progression wise is some what ambiguous. Other than that management can be micro managing at times but apparent in all sales jobs too.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Tampines New Town,
pros: Large organization and lots of work to do..
cons: Too much bureaucracy and very hierarchical/ political

review_title: Not a good place to be ITPM
pros: None that I know of
cons: Not a good place to be ITPM. Very political and ITPM is often thrown under the bus. Lack of support from other teams / departments, and blamed for whatever issue coming the project's way.

job_title: Please Select Region, State Or Province in Singapore
pros: Family oriented, friendly environment and nice colleagues. Good recognition for good performance. overall quite a good place to work in.
cons: Do expect to work on weekends if you are in the sales and marketing role. Hard for internal transfer if we will like to switch roles

review_title: Great environment however growth dependent on backing
pros:
- Great environment, family warmth
- Friendly competition
cons:
- Not much room for growth and exposure, constricted to a small area 
- Management tends to practice favoritism (Note: OCBC is big, may not be the same for all areas)

pros:
People are generally nice and friendly
Competitive pay package
Managers that really care about each individual's career path and development
cons:
There are tensions between departments due to different priorities
High expectations from senior management

review_title: Not worth even going for interview, bad culture
pros: None nothing at all is good
cons: They are very biased bank. Even differentiate between male and female employees, they cant and should not ever talk of diversity as they are genuinely not even bothered. Late working hours are usual

pros:
Humane place - no retrenchment even in d economic downturn
Good marketing strategies
cons:
Low pay
Horrible work-life balance
Employees dont feel valued
People are promoted when theres budget, not when they deserve to be

review_title: Good welfare, but also make full use of employees
pros: Good benefits and welfare with strong local culture.
cons: Labour is maximized and poor manpower planning. Overpromise and underdeliver in progression.

review_title: Good place to learn your basics
pros: Forgiving work environment. Okay to make mistakes. Good work life balance. Rarely need to do overtime.
cons: Pay based on academic qualification (for fresh grads) and does not consider work experience. Difficult to progress. Poor internal systems.

review_title: Local culture and above average welfare benefits organisation
pros: Good leave benefits for married staff. Provides opportunity for staff to upgrade through in-house trainings and taking part-time degree.
cons: Requires working on occasional weekends. Promotion tends to scale towards tenor of service rather than merits for middle management and employees.

review_title: Looks good from the outside, quite bad on the inside
pros:
A lot of leave days
Good place to retire
Procedures well written
cons:
Paper intensive 
Backward systems
Understaffed, overworked
Too many approval levels
Audit only cares about finding your mistakes

pros: Friendly working environment. Inter Divisional communication is equal. Good work life balance. Especially well family benefits such as childcare center for working parents.
cons: Friendly working environment. Inter Divisional communication is equal. Good work life balance. Especially well family benefits such as childcare center for working parent

pros: Good opportunities to learn and they invest in a lot of systems to grow their business. Nice colleagues
cons: Lotsa approvals before things can get done. Processes can sometimes be manual

pros: Sufficient number of Leaves, flexi benefit is attractive, reputable bank, good system compare to other banks.
cons: Long Working Hours, Need to work over weekends, Need to cold calling, Very Sales Oriented. If you are very sales driven, then it is suitable for you

pros: It was a great experience. Had opportunities to be involved in indursty projects instead of data entry. Boss and colleagues are willing to teach and help along the way.

review_title: Feudalistic System if you're not based in SG(HQ)
pros: 1.You only do what you're hired to do 2.Stable, ok work life balance(depends on your hiring manager) 3. Minimal politics for non-P&L departments. 4. Departing CEO farewell email commented high proportion of intra-couples
cons: 1.Feudalistic system ex-SG ie 90-95% of profits are sucked by HQ, leaving behind meagre increments (if any) and minimal bonus.Periodic mass attrition of whole depts are common. After a time, feels like a nike sweat shop ie. daily grind of sop activities with ho-hum bonus, 0 or minimal increment yet self-serving congratulatory messsages by senior management on a job well done on maintaining staff morale (reeks of hypocrisy) 2. Local management has no independent authority to hire/promote, everything is decided by HQ; do not be fooled by the media positive statements. The first question you should ask from the positive comments is are they from SG or ex-SG ? 3.A huge gap in term of talent recognition, reward and career progression of ex-SG talents. VP's are a dime in a dozen in SG ie within 1-3 years, an AVP can be promoted to VP in SG. by just managing projects ie sending emails etc. Ex-SG average timeline for promotion to VP is 7 years; regardless of his/her contributions; he/she can be the pioneer/ innovator and still not be recognized.
